description: From Middle English patroun, patrone, from Old French patron, from Latin patrōnus, derived from pater (“father”). Doublet of pattern.

definitionGroups.group: One who protects or supports; a defender or advocate.

entries.meaning: A guardian or intercessor; synonym of patron saint.
examples: St. Joseph is the patron of many different places.

entries.meaning: An influential, wealthy person who supported an artist, craftsman, a scholar or a noble.
A customer, as of a certain store or restaurant.
examples: This car park is for patrons only.

entries.meaning: (historical, Roman law) A protector of a dependent, especially a master who had freed a slave but still retained some paternal rights.
(UK, ecclesiastical) One who has gift and disposition of a benefice.
(obsolete or historical) A property owner, a landlord, a master. (Compare patroon.)
examples: [...] would obtain permission from the West India Company to settle in certain areas in the New World and cultivate the land. Sometimes absentee patrons would give the colony to a group of interested persons and the patrons would finance ...

verbs.description: patron (third-person singular simple present patrons, present participle patroning, simple past and past participle patroned)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To be a patron of; to patronize; to favour.
(transitive, obsolete) To treat as a patron.
